title: Barry Du Bois tells of how a positive attitude has helped him through his terminal cancer diagnosis
text:
TV star Barry Du Bois has told of how an overwhelmingly positive attitude has helped him through his terminal cancer diagnosis.

Barry, 59, is best known for hosting Channel 10's the Living Room and was diagnosed with multiple myeloma in 2017 after having gone through a different cancer previously.

The condition is incurable and the TV host told The Project on Friday that he is currently undergoing intensive experimental treatment for a fighting chance.

'They told me three months the first time': appearing on The Project on Friday, Barry Du Bois (pictured) revealed his 'positive attitude' has helped him outlive his terminal cancer prognosis

'I'm up for a tough gig ahead. At Christmas time, when we are on holidays, I'm going to be in an isolation ward,' he said.

Despite his refreshed and stylish appearance Barry's body is riddled with tumours and issues.

'I have a whole bunch of giant tumours, like big holes in my body. In my pelvis I've got a big one in my thigh.'

Fellow Channel 10 host Lisa Wilkinson asked him about the state of his prognosis.

Barry told Lisa Wilkinson: 'I learnt early in life, that if you invest in negativity, there is literally no dividend'. He hopes to outlive his five-year prognosis. Pictured on The Project

'Are the doctors telling you five years?' she asked.

'That's the statistics. They told me three months the first time,' he said.

'I learnt early in life, that if you invest in negativity, there is literally no dividend.

'Look if I smile at you that's a relatively easy investment - Look I smiled at you and you smiled back, that's a beautiful dividend,' he said to Lisa.

Family first: Barry (pictured with his children Arabella and Bennett) was diagnosed with multiple myeloma in 2017 after already having gone through cancer previously

Barry previously told Australian Men's Health while he considers himself to be an optimist, the thought of his lasting memory being so negative for his children has been on the forefront of his mind.

He has changed his focus to strengthening his mental health, while still taking steps to keep in shape and gradually build up his physical strength.

'What I have is not curable. But I'm in a great place. I'm as good as someone can be who has multiple myeloma,' he said.
description: TV star Barry Du Bois has told of how an overwhelmingly positive attitude has helped him through his terminal cancer diagnosis.
authors: Tom Place For Daily Mail Australia
